title: Under what circumstances can back child support payable to the State (in CA) be discharged in chapter 7. Ex was on welfare b4.
question: Owe quite a bit of money in back child support most of which is payable to the government. When is this discharged and would I have to do anything special in a chapter 7 or just list it as a debt?
answers:
There is a small loophole in Chapter 13s for property equalization debts to a former spouse but I do not think any debt classified as "support" is going to fall into that category.

While even property equalization debts cannot be discharged in Chapter 7 pursuant to 11 U.S.C. 523(a)(15), crafty divorce attorneys have been getting around this by characterizing payments that might otherwise be support as equalization for other property. Because California is a community property state, equalization debts can legitimately arise in a divorce decree but I think they are now put there strategically by lawyers who want to be able to discharge their clients promises via a Chapter 13 at a later date.

Nevertheless, I don't think based on your facts that this loophole applies in your situation.

Best regards,
Hamid

There is a loophole that can allow discharge of a child support debt owed to a governmental unit, but I believe it is only available through a Chapter 13. This is something that only comes up every once in a while & I would have to research it to be sure.

Anyone else remember how this works?
As stated in the first reply, child support cannot be discharged in bankruptcy.
Domestic Support (Alimony/Child Support) is not dischargeable in bankruptcy.
